Comment: White starts things off with the most popular opening, the King's Pawn Opening.
Black responds with the King's Pawn Game.
White continues with the King's knight opening, which I expected, for I use it all the time.
I continue the King's Pawn Game.
White brings out the Scotch Opening.
I respond with the Scotch Relfsson Gambit, which I usually play in the Scotch.
As expected, white responds with the Scotch game.
Black goes ahead with the Scotch Ghulam Kassim variation.
As I expected, the Scotch continues.
Black continues the Scotch.
The Scotch ends. So with the traditional game openings over with, anything can happen at this point.
White attacks the queen.
Not what I totally expected, but this can easily be countered.
Based on computer analysis: Mistake. Best: Bc6. I can see why. The b7 the pawn was completely unprotected, so white could gain a slight advantage here both in points and in position.
Based on computer analysis: Mistake. Best: Bc6. I can see why. The b7 the pawn was completely unprotected, so white could gain a slight advantage here both in points and in position.
Based on computer analysis: Mistake. Best: Bc6. I can see why. The b7 the pawn was completely unprotected, so white could gain a slight advantage here both in points and in position.
Fortunately for black, white instead responds with Bb5. The computer analysis sees this as a mistake of course.
I decide to except a swap, although this will put me in check again.
I still wish to castle...
...so I use my queen to protect me. This will keep me from castling though if white accepts a fair trade.
Fortunately for black, white wants to keep his queen.
With black's queen out of the way, black decides to castle queen-side.
